Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Communicate with clients and vendors regarding financial matters.
Situation2: A major supplier has threatened to halt all future shipments until a significant past-due invoice is settled.
Story: I stared at my phone, my mother’s message glowing on the screen: “Don’t forget, you’re leading the ceremony tonight. It means so much to your grandmother.” My heart thudded. This ceremony was a cornerstone of our family’s tradition, and everyone expected me to honor it, to show respect and keep our values alive. But as I tried to focus, my work email pinged again. The subject line: “URGENT: Supplier Halting Shipments.” My boss’s message was clear—if I didn’t resolve the overdue invoice with our major supplier today, our operations could grind to a halt. I was supposed to call the supplier, negotiate, and reassure them, all before the end of business hours. My mind raced, torn between the weight of my family’s expectations and the pressing demands of my job. I could feel the pressure mounting, my sense of responsibility pulling me in two directions at once, each role demanding my full attention, neither willing to wait.
